Cataglyphis hispanica is known to be active during the hottest parts of the day, when other ant species may be inactive. This is achieved through various physiological and behavioral mechanisms, such as the ability to dissipate heat and the use of specialized cooling strategies.

The ecology of Cataglyphis hispanica is closely tied to the arid and semi-arid habitats of the Iberian Peninsula. They play an important role in the ecosystem as predators and scavengers, contributing to the regulation of insect populations and the decomposition of organic matter.

Overall, Cataglyphis hispanica is a fascinating example of how ants have adapted to thrive in challenging environments, showcasing their remarkable navigational skills and thermal tolerance.
